it could have a significant impact
on your litigation
for a good number of years to come.
Another area of litigation
that's going on
is in the area of security clearances.
Security clearances are necessary
for many people
who work for the government
or work for private industry
that do contracts with the government,
generally in the areas
of energy and defense.
And what security clearance means
is that the government says
that you are okay
to look at classified information
and feel that you're not going
to default this information.
There's different levels
of security clearances.
Gay people over the years
have had a great deal
of problems
with getting security clearances.
And what we've found
is that the government's policy
on this is somewhat inconsistent.
They do not have
an interagency plan
or a set of guidelines
or criteria.
Each agency decides on its own.
And there's an awful lot
of discretion
that can be exercised.
What we've found
is a recent trend
where in many agencies
a person can get
a security clearance.
Some can get
a security clearance
and some can get
a security clearance
and some can get
a security clearance
and some can get
a security clearance
and some can get
a security clearance
and some can get
security clearance
yummy here.
Some agencies,
so-called intelligence agencies,
I call them
the police agencies,
the FBI,
the CIA,
the national security agency,
are hanging in
their tough etudes
and they will not
grant security clearances
to anybody
that they know is gay.
There's been
some recent litigation
against the CIA.
There was one case
that was filed
more than a year ago
in the District
of Columbia District Court,
it's before Judge
Barrington-Parker.
And he has been
sitting on motions
for summary judgment
case for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles in the
Worcester court down there involving John Green who was an engineer with a company
known as TRW. He's worked with TRW I believe for 13 years and he's never had any problems. The CIA in fact has never said that he leaked any information,
divulged any information, but basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to
blackmail when he was gay and therefore might divulge information. So that argument breaks down when the person says I'm not

subject to blackmail. I'm open about my sexuality. My family knows, my friends know. It's no big deal to me. I don't know why it's a big deal to you, but to the CIA it's still a big deal and they can't, they just cannot understand why there might be some kind of, or might not be some kind of problem here.
So that case is pending.
USG

in the Worcester court. The government just yesterday filed its brief, they filed a motion to dismiss. They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case based on solemn immunity. They said the government did not consent to be sued in this case. And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government by getting involved in this matter. They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not.
So they will be responsible for filing that on March 2nd.

I'll talk only about two more issues. One is briefly some First Amendment cases that we're involved in. We find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco we have the Bay Area Reporter, are being censored at a number of prisons around the country. Prisons want to keep in touch with their gay communities.
Not being allowed to read these papers.

So we're going to be involved in a suit probably, if we do for the luck of the Congressional Correctional Act Institute in Kentucky, and maybe one here at the Lompoc prison, and possibly one down at Texas as well.
And then last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University in成長.
I graduated from Michigan State University in成長. So I graduated from Michigan State University in成長.

State University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes. And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events. And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day past students' intersections. We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us.

So we filed an action against the university. We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from some of our sources, post-administration, that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year, because they were probably in some pretty serious trouble.
So the next year, we made an application to put up the banner and ended up without any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971,
last year, they allowed gay students to be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot, and it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on. We found that there's another school called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they allege they're gay.
There's a private college in the suburbs of Chicago.

They once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework, and said this person's gay, and he doesn't meet the good moral character requirements of our schools, and he can't handle his degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has official, granted official university recognition to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space, or any funding, or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas, right now, involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus,
and my last big gay rights case before I came to the west coast involved the lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, DC,
because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate, into the law school, gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students.
As well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent here in California.
It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community as sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about.
It's writing this new book about the black people of this country.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality if they have not reached any consent?
Because that seems to be something in California that is sort of an issue.
And it's very hard to consider.
Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take is a...
We basically wait for people to come to us, which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
If a day doesn't go by, they don't get at least one call.
So I'm not concerned about some kind of discrimination or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
The thing that you do talk about is in housing.
Some of my members have been pointing out that this city, Denver, has a law that says two of the remaining individuals cannot live together.
This is often used against gay couples.
What's the status of that?
Has it been done yet?
We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright as saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure.
It wasn't necessarily anti-gay, but it was intended to keep noise down and to protect sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly didn't have an impact on gay people.
Some of the things like that, it's very subtle with legislation.
In some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.
